claim: It's always humid in Hong Kong.

supporting.text: Hong Kong has a subtropical climate with high humidity levels throughout most of the year, especially during the summer months.

attacks.text: Hong Kong has a subtropical climate with high humidity levels throughout most of the year, especially during the summer months.
Hong Kong experiences dry periods during winter months when humidity levels drop significantly.
Urban areas in Hong Kong may have lower humidity due to air conditioning and concrete surfaces reducing moisture retention.
Even during winter, the humidity in Hong Kong remains relatively high compared to many other regions, rarely dropping below 60%.
The localized effect of urban areas does not negate the overall high humidity levels across the territory, especially in rural and coastal areas.
60% humidity in winter is not considered high by subtropical climate standards, as many similar regions experience much drier conditions.
Rural and coastal areas constitute a smaller portion of Hong Kong's total inhabited area, making urban conditions more representative for most residents.

supporting.text: The proximity of Hong Kong to the South China Sea contributes to consistently high humidity due to maritime influence.

attacks.text: The proximity of Hong Kong to the South China Sea contributes to consistently high humidity due to maritime influence.
Hong Kong experiences dry seasons where humidity levels drop significantly, contradicting the claim of 'always humid'.
Urban areas in Hong Kong, such as Kowloon, often have lower humidity due to the urban heat island effect reducing moisture retention.
Modern infrastructure like air conditioning and dehumidifiers in buildings can locally reduce humidity, making it not 'always humid' indoors.
Even during dry seasons, Hong Kong's humidity rarely falls below 60%, which is still considered high by global standards.
The urban heat island effect in Kowloon is offset by the surrounding sea breeze, maintaining relatively high humidity.
Indoor humidity control does not negate the overall climate, as outdoor humidity remains consistently high throughout the year.
A humidity level of 60% is not universally considered high; many regions experience much higher levels regularly.
Sea breeze effects are often blocked by high-rise buildings in urban areas, reducing their impact on humidity.

supporting.text: Hong Kong experiences frequent rainfall, which adds to the overall humidity levels in the region.

attacks.text: Hong Kong experiences frequent rainfall, which adds to the overall humidity levels in the region.
Rainfall does not necessarily correlate with high humidity, as humidity depends on evaporation rates and temperature, not just precipitation.
Hong Kong has dry seasons where humidity levels drop significantly, contradicting the claim that it is always humid.
Even during dry seasons, the proximity to the ocean ensures that humidity remains relatively high compared to inland areas.
Evaporation rates are high in Hong Kong due to its tropical climate, which means rainfall does contribute significantly to humidity levels.
Ocean proximity alone does not guarantee high humidity; wind patterns and seasonal changes can override this effect.
High evaporation rates can also lead to drier conditions if the moisture is carried away by winds, not necessarily increasing humidity.

supporting.text: During the winter months, humidity levels in Hong Kong can drop significantly, making it less humid compared to other seasons.

attacks.text: During the winter months, humidity levels in Hong Kong can drop significantly, making it less humid compared to other seasons.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's humidity levels remain relatively high compared to many other cities, so it is still considered humid.
Winter humidity drops are temporary and do not negate the overall high humidity experienced throughout most of the year in Hong Kong.
Relative humidity is not the only measure of perceived humidity; dew point and absolute humidity also play a role, and these can remain high even in winter.
The claim states 'always,' which implies consistency, so occasional drops in humidity do not invalidate the general trend of high humidity.
Perceived humidity is subjective and can vary among individuals, so even if metrics show lower humidity in winter, it may still feel humid to many people.

supporting.text: Air conditioning and urban infrastructure in Hong Kong can reduce perceived humidity in indoor environments, making it not always humid in all areas.

attacks.text: Air conditioning and urban infrastructure in Hong Kong can reduce perceived humidity in indoor environments, making it not always humid in all areas.
Outdoor humidity levels in Hong Kong remain consistently high regardless of indoor conditions, so the claim still holds for the overall environment.
Not all indoor spaces in Hong Kong have effective air conditioning or infrastructure to reduce humidity, so humidity is still a pervasive issue.
High outdoor humidity still affects indoor environments when people move between spaces, making humidity a constant factor.
Many public and older buildings in Hong Kong lack modern humidity control, reinforcing that humidity is widespread.
Even with transitions between indoor and outdoor spaces, many workplaces and homes maintain stable low-humidity conditions, mitigating the overall effect.

supporting.text: Cold fronts from the north during winter can bring drier air to Hong Kong, temporarily reducing humidity levels.

attacks.text: Cold fronts from the north during winter can bring drier air to Hong Kong, temporarily reducing humidity levels.
Cold fronts are infrequent and short-lived, so their impact on overall humidity is negligible.
Even during cold fronts, humidity levels often remain high compared to other regions.
The temporary reduction in humidity is offset by the persistent high humidity during other seasons.
Studies show that cold fronts significantly lower humidity for weeks, not just temporarily.
Hong Kong's coastal location ensures that humidity remains high even during cold fronts.
The overall annual humidity average is still very high despite seasonal variations.
The duration of cold fronts is too short to have a meaningful impact on annual humidity averages.
Coastal influence is not strong enough to counteract the drying effect of cold fronts.
